item.title: Priti Patel promises overhaul of asylum seeker rules
item.description: Refugees who arrive legally can stay in the UK, but failed applicants will be removed under the new plans.

item.title: UK shines 'beacon of remembrance'
item.description: Candlelight vigils were held across the country in remembrance of those who lost their lives in the pandemic.

item.title: 'Greed' and 'capitalism' helped UK's vaccines success, says PM
item.description: But Boris Johnson immediately retracts the comments during a Zoom meeting with Tory MPs.

item.title: Egypt's Suez Canal blocked by large container ship
item.description: Several tug boats are deployed to shift the vessel, which is causing a build-up of shipping traffic.

item.title: Kill the Bill Bristol protests: Police action at demo
item.description: Police officers arrest demonstrators protesting in the city centre at the new police bill.

item.title: North Korea missiles: Biden says launch 'not provocation'
item.description: The short-range missile test is the first to be conducted since the US president took office.

item.title: Child abuse: Warning of siblings being groomed online
item.description: The rise of livestreaming platforms is making it easier for paedophiles to target children, experts say.

item.title: Israel election: Netanyahu falls short of majority in exit polls
item.description: The PM's Likud party and its allies are projected to win 52 or 53 seats in the 120-seat Knesset.

item.title: Ex-Manchester United player Ronnie Wallwork fractured man's eye socket in trainers' row
item.description: Ronnie Wallwork, who also played for West Bromwich Albion, admitted an assault charge.

item.title: UK seeks to drill more oil and gas from North Sea
item.description: More oil and gas wells are to be drilled in the North Sea, the UK government announces.

item.title: Harry to become chief impact officer at US coaching firm BetterUp
item.description: The Duke of Sussex is "really excited" to become chief impact officer for coaching firm BetterUp.

item.title: The Papers: PM's Covid 'regrets' and children in line for August jab
item.description: Wednesday's front pages reflect on the country's tributes to those who died in the pandemic.

item.title: Anti-Asian hate: 'Try to be brave and stand up'
item.description: Amid nationwide rallies against anti-Asian hate crimes, we ask what it is like to be an Asian woman in the US.

item.title: Autistic boy's lockdown quotes turned into art
item.description: Woody's inspirational lockdown quotes have been turned into artwork by his dad.

item.title: Russia's Tajik-born Eurovision star on the abuse she's received
item.description: In an interview with the BBC, Russia’s entrant for the Eurovision Song Contest 2021 has spoken of the hatred she’s received.

item.title: Lockdown anniversary: Hospital workers on a year of Covid
item.description: Four staff from University Hospital Southampton reflect on the last year on their home and work lives.

item.title: Wales election 2021: Who should I vote for? Compare party policies
item.description: Compare where the parties stand on key issues - from Covid-19 and the NHS to education and the environment.

item.title: New Mastermind host Clive Myrie put to the test
item.description: BBC Breakfast has a few questions for the new quiz show host.

item.title: Covid-19: One year of lockdowns across the UK
item.description: It's a year to the day since the first UK-wide coronavirus lockdown was announced.

item.title: 'I was working 72 hours a week - it was cult-like'
item.description: As first-year Goldman Sachs analysts ask for a cap on their hours, four BBC News readers share their schedules.

item.title: Loneliness: 'Alone is ok, but being lonely - it hurts'
item.description: A report by MPs and peers is calling on ministers to reconnect communities and combat loneliness after coronavirus.

item.title: Lockdown job-hunting: ‘I’ve applied for over 300 jobs’
item.description: If you've spent lockdown looking for jobs, you're not alone... But help is here.

item.title: 2021 elections: A really simple guide
item.description: A bumper crop of elections are being held on 6 May across England, Scotland and Wales.

item.title: Australia floods: 'Saving a home from fires to lose it in floods'
item.description: Rob Costigan fought desperately to save his home from fires last year - now it's been destroyed by floods.

item.title: Fears for democracy as buoyant Bangladesh turns 50
item.description: Half a century after its birth, millions are no longer in poverty - but democratic space has shrunk.

item.title: Has Nicola Sturgeon emerged from this crisis unscathed?
item.description: The first minister's position is stronger than it has been for weeks - but her government has not escaped criticism.

item.title: How Iceland clamped down to conquer coronavirus
item.description: It may be a remote island, but there is a reason why Iceland is proud of its success in tackling the pandemic.

item.title: Brora stun Hearts in one of biggest shocks in Scottish Cup history
item.description: Highland League Brora Rangers knock last season's beaten finalists, Hearts, out of the Scottish Cup in a huge second-round shock.

item.title: 'It was difficult watching from home' - recalled Stones on his England exile
item.description: John Stones says he felt helpless having to watch England on TV after being recalled to the squad for the first time since November 2019.

item.title: Pitchside saliva test to diagnose concussion has 'game-changing' trial
item.description: Using pitchside saliva tests to diagnose concussion is a step closer after a "game-changing" trial in rugby union.

item.title: England lose first ODI to India despite Bairstow's brilliant 94
item.description: England squander the chance to win a fluctuating first one-day international against India, losing by 66 runs in Pune.

item.title: Ineos Grenadiers co-owner Ratcliffe backs under-fire Brailsford
item.description: Ineos Grenadiers co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe says general manager Sir Dave Brailsford has his backing in the wake of Richard Freeman's tribunal.

item.title: England coach Jones' fate hinges on 'brutally honest' RFU review
item.description: Eddie Jones' future as England coach will hinge on a "brutally honest" review into their Six Nations performance, says RFU boss Bill Sweeney.

item.title: 'My plan is to go back to Real' - Bale says club future 'no distraction'
item.description: Tottenham's on-loan forward Gareth Bale says he plans to return to Real Madrid next season.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Wales and Scotland have announced the easing of restrictions on people meeting

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: Anyone in England who travels abroad without good reason will soon face a £5000 fine.

item.title: Covid: How are European countries tackling the pandemic?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Will I need a vaccine passport and can employers demand workers get vaccinated?
item.description: A review is considering whether people will need to be vaccinated to work in care or attend large events.

item.title: Unemployment rate: How many people are out of work?
item.description: The unemployment rate is rising as Covid hits different parts of the economy.

item.title: Covid: The inside story of the government's battle against the virus
item.description: Twenty of Downing Street's most senior politicians, officials and former officials take you "into the room" where essential Covid decisions were being made.

item.title: Covid: The countries that nailed it, and what we can learn from them
item.description: A year into the pandemic, we look at countries that have had some success in tackling the virus.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Coronavirus: Your tributes to those who have died
item.description: A collection of your tributes to some of the thousands of people in the UK who have died with coronavirus.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People aged 50 and over are the latest group to be invited to book their Covid vaccine.

item.title: Covid: What is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine?
item.description: The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccines should save many lives, say experts.

item.title: Coronavirus: Where does the government borrow billions from?
item.description: How does it work when a government wants to borrow money, and when does it have to pay it back?

item.title: Covid: More walking and family chats post-lockdown - poll suggests
item.description: We've done more walking and worked more from home this year, according to a BBC-commissioned poll.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as almost 28 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid-19: Have a million people left the UK?
item.description: How far has the UK's foreign-born population fallen during the coronavirus pandemic?

item.title: Coronavirus: When will pubs, hairdressers and gyms open?
item.description: Lockdown is being eased, so when will places like hairdressers, pubs and gyms open?

item.title: Covid: What’s the problem with the EU vaccine rollout?
item.description: The coronavirus vaccine is being rolled out across the EU but there have been delays.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the R number and how is it calculated?
item.description: The R number is a simple but crucial figure at the heart of lockdown decisions across the UK.

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should be shielding and why?
item.description: Shielding in England will end on 31 March.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Covid-19: EU warns UK over vaccine exports
item.description: The EU threatens to block vaccine exports to the UK unless it "gets its fair share".

item.title: Coronavirus: How are the rules for weddings changing across the UK?
item.description: Wedding ceremonies are still restricted across the UK, but there are plans to ease the rules.

item.title: EU plans for a 'vaccine passport' to allow travel
item.description: 'Vaccine passport' plans have been proposed by the EU, in order to make travel easier this summer.

item.title: Covid: When will children return to school and what are the rules?
item.description: Children are returning to school across the UK, after months of enforced home-schooling.

item.title: Lockdown Learning: What educational resources are on TV, iPlayer and online?
item.description: As most pupils return to school, the BBC will continue to offer a wealth of educational material.

item.title: Coronavirus: Data by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: What are the care home rules in England?
item.description: New guidance gives hope to relatives wanting to visit care homes.

item.title: What are the new rules for testing and hotel quarantine?
item.description: Travellers going to and from the UK face a growing number of restrictions.

item.title: Am I eligible for the new furlough scheme?
item.description: Furlough has been extended until the end of September.

item.title: North Korea’s ‘only openly gay defector’ finds love
item.description: Jang Yeong-jin fled North Korea to escape a loveless marriage. Now he is engaged to his boyfriend.
